section.title: &xml; Representation
section.para: Issues may be represented in &xml;, both in the inner workings of an &idb; implementation, and in user-visible output. The latter includes exported &xml; and use of &xml; in user interfaces, such as in the e-mail interface.

section.title: Issue &dtd;
section.programlisting:
<!ELEMENT issue (class, iid, field-data*)>
<!ELEMENT field-data (field*)> <!ATTLIST field-data revision-number CDATA #OPTIONAL>
<!ELEMENT class (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT iid (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT field (#PCDATA | attachment | item*)> <!ATTLIST field name CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!ELEMENT item (#PCDATA | attachment)>
<!ELEMENT attachment (description mime-type external-name)>
<!ELEMENT description (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT mime-type (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT external-name (#PCDATA)>
section.para:
The formal public identifier for this &dtd; is
"-//Software Carpentry//DTD QMTrack V0.1//EN"

&xml; representations of an issue will normally present a single revision only, namely the latest revision. In this case, the <issue> element will contain only a single <field-data> element, and the the revision-numer attribute is supressed. For &xml;-based &idb; implementations in which multiple revisions are stored together, multiple <field-data> elements will be included with different revision-numer values. The &idb; implementation may choose to store difference issue records instead of the entire field data for past revision, i.e. for the next-most-recent and previous revisions, only fields that were changes are included in the <field-data> element.

The <field> element is used for all issue fields. For set fields, the contents are zero or more item tags, each corresponding to an element of the set. For attachment fields, the contents are an <attachment> element. Other field types are represented with CDATA.

The second component of the <attachment> element is the attachment's MIME type. The third component, <external-name>, is a file name or other identifier for the location of the attachment data. For disk-based &idb; implementations, it will contain a relative path to a file. For e-mail &xml; issue representations, it will contain the name of a MIME attachment included in the e-mail message.

section.title: &xml; example
section.para:
Below is an example of an issue for a compiler bug report.
<?xml version="1.0"?> <!DOCTYPE issue PUBLIC "-//Software Carpentry//DTD QMTrack V0.1//EN"> <issue> <class>bug</class> <iid>17</iid> <field-data> <field name="categories"> <item>front end</item> <item>C++</item> </field> <field name="severity">severe</field> <field name="priority">4</field> <field name="description">"Internal Compiler Error" in parser.</field> <field name="input"> <![CDATA[ int foo (char* p) { return *p = *(++p); } ]]> </field> <field name="flags">-g -O2</field> <field name="attachments"> <item> <attachment> <description>core file</description> <mime-type>application/octet-stream</mime-type> <external-name>attachment001</external-name> </attachment> </item> </field> </field-data> </issue>

This example is an issue in the issue class "bug", which is used for bug reports (as opposed to, for instance, feature requests or reports of documentation errors). The issue id is "17", and the issue is included in two categories: "back end" and "C++".

In addition to the standard "severity", "priority", and "description" fields, the "bug" issue class includes two other fields specifically added for recording information about compiler bugs. The "flags" field describes the command-line options that should be specified when inoking the compiler to reproduce the problem. The "input" field contains the input source code. Since the "input" field contains program text that is likely to contain special characters, the field contents are placed in a CDATA element.

The "attachment" field in the "bug" issue class contains a set of zero or more file attachments. For this bug, one attachment is included: a core file generated by the crashing compiler. The MIME type is "application/octet-stream", since core files are usually treated as binary data. The data itself is stored in an object named "attachment001". The location of this object is context-dependent; if the &xml; issue record is in the &idb;, it is stored in a file by that name, while if the issue record is included in an e-mail message, it will be included as an attachment with that name.
